topic.title: How do i reset a whole site?
topic.body:
I did update the 08ch code to current millchan version, like threads in /tech/ suggested, because on millchan i am able to post pics while on 08ch i am not.... and this messed up my shit, i couldn't publish anything anymore because of >Content publish failed with every connection on publishing getting a Timeout error in the zeronet log.... so i reverted back to the backup, and it still didn't solve the issue... so i deleted the whole data/blablabla folder of 08ch, and now i can't access it, probably because of 
>KeyError: 'content.json' in UiWebsocket.py line 194 that pops up in the log.

Just fuck my shit up

topic.title: No filesharing site?
topic.body:
So you are telling me that you built a whole decentralized www using P2P technology and there is not a single filesharing site?
I would have expected something like thepiratebay, just without proxysites that regularly get taken down and without spyware and without the need of a BitTorrent client.

Even a 1:1 copy of thepiratebay, where you still use a BitTorrent client, would be great

topic.title: How do i get a new identity address?
topic.body:
I can change it, i can get a new one when i visit a new site, but i can't delete it and can't just create a new one without going to a new site.
Or am i just retarded?

Respect each others feelings, don't offend anybody, use correct pronouns.

1565188740_1JpWZr3hPmL8cYSKQCzuqUyhG25Uu.body:
> [plasm](#comment_2_129uWu4oE98C98BFC2GoJGSq51RetSBP4f): hopefully you are correct.

i am here to stay, faggot

No, honestly, when i saw that its some python script, i didn't think that this would look so good, but it does. Respect to you guys for launching something like that.
Just that the Tor settings aren't on "Always" per default and you potentionally let everyone who browses something that you browse without Tor know your IP, is a huge privacy issue. Should make something like a huge note that this can happen and a big recommendation for usng socks proxy or tor on Always.

Even more scarry is that the new CDN they used got shut down by their infrastructure provider.
While every site can choose another CDN or run without CDN and you can switch as fast as a DNS update gets distributed, you can't do anything when some public company on the backbone decides to shut you down.

Basically the only way to get a internet without getting randomly censored by some company for something that you did that's not even against the law (the shooter posted his manifesto on instagram first, so why not shut that down too, while you are at it?) is to lay your own cables or go full ham radio autist.
Having to cuck yourself with Tor + proxies + p2p hosting and all those issues and honey pots just to escape that is dumb and then you get yourself fucked through association because some fag distributes child porn and you weren't fast enough with closing it.

is there some site where i can check my IP that i use to connect to other peers?
So that i know that i know for sure that i am behind tor without my IP leaking for non-tor users?

> [anonkraut](#comment_4_1JpWZr3hPmL8cYSKQCzuqUyhG25UuQsjPh):
Thank you, got it.
One more question:
Per default the P2P connections run through tor hidden service, except to peers that do not use Tor, if i set the Tor settings in zeronet to "Always"... what exactly happenes now to connections to peers without Tor?
If they don't use Tor, they can't connect to my Tor hidden service that zeronet uses, so all connections to them are established from me towards them?

Is there some documentation where i can read how that specific case from tor to non-tor works?

Small personal blog post:
So i got now all settings correct and i can't see a single connection from zeronet in netstat that doesn't go through  the Tor Browser tor instance.
Seems  like i don't run into the risk of getting into jail for hosting cp now, just because i accidentally clicked on something where a retard posted cp.

Thanks bros, its awesome what you built here, and it was easy to setup.

Btw. this really reminds me of the times when ham radio was a thing. 
Autists doing their own thing so that they don't rely on old shitty telephones.... or just because they can.

> [redlibertyreal](#comment_55_1D6UcmziWg55aXV6TnCksXpjsFJ4gDK6Kw)
I'd just like to interject for moment. What you're refering to as Linux, is in fact, GNU/Linux, or as I've recently taken to calling it, GNU plus Linux. Linux is not an operating system unto itself, but rather another free component of a fully functioning GNU system made useful by the GNU corelibs, shell utilities and vital system components comprising a full OS as defined by POSIX.

Many computer users run a modified version of the GNU system every day, without realizing it. Through a peculiar turn of events, the version of GNU which is widely used today is often called Linux, and many of its users are not aware that it is basically the GNU system, developed by the GNU Project.

There really is a Linux, and these people are using it, but it is just a part of the system they use. Linux is the kernel: the program in the system that allocates the machine's resources to the other programs that you run. The kernel is an essential part of an operating system, but useless by itself; it can only function in the context of a complete operating system. Linux is normally used in combination with the GNU operating system: the whole system is basically GNU with Linux added, or GNU/Linux. All the so-called Linux distributions are really distributions of GNU/Linux!

1565951931_16VcDM9UrXq4VY2MAKJhfuiN1DoG5.body:
There is the multiuser plugin that you can enable in Hello-Page -> Three dots -> Plugins. This plugin then manages the IDs with cookies and allows you to remove one and reuse another one or just creating a new one.
But this plugin is not so good if you use a browser that doesn't save cookies.

Alternatively you could move/delete the data/users.json file in the zeronet folder. This file holds your IDs. If its gone, you can create new IDs.

> [trevorlaneray](#comment_51_12eXcQ1ojAbyCoCcMQ3JAKi73wgcJrjow3): Wait, if the multiuser plugin uses cookies to manage identities, does it export identities from users.json to cookies, but not use the users.json file once you start using it?Or does it keep users.json file up-to-date with the cookie-based identities you create and manage?

As i tested it, it ignored the identities from users.json completely and didn't update it. The multiuser plugin requires you to copy the key and store it yourself somewhere in order to reuse old identities.
I guess the thought process behind that plugin was to move the id management from the file to cookies.

well, my experience with the multiuser plugin (on tor browser, wich rejects tracking cookies and stuff) was that i lost all identities and that it wouldn't remember them and that i couldn't even turn off the plugin, because the Plugin site would give me an invalid private key error.

So my experience doesn't count very much.
(just remember that you can manually turn it off by removing data/plugins.json in case that this happens to you)

I have to add that all other people that i saw who tried it (at least three) didn't report any problems with it.
I am ok with moving/deleting users.json, so i didn't play too much with the plugin after it gave me an horrible experience when i first tried it.
It could have just been some super obscure special case... but imho it does make sense that a plugin that uses cookies would not work very well if you don't save cookies.
